titlestmt.titleproper: A guide to the Benjamin E. Washburn papers FA038
titlestmt.author: Martha Briggs

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2016-08-10 00:00:31 -0400.

change.item: Migrated from Re:discovery to the Archivists' Toolkit by Becky Robbins

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the userâ€™s responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: A physician, public health officer, and author, Benjamin E. Washburn was born in Rutherford County, North Carolina, in 1885. Dr. Washburn received undergraduate (1906) and graduate (1909) degrees in English and history from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and graduated from the University of Virginia in 1911 with a degree in medicine. It was during his internship in Wilmington, North Carolina, that he met Zillah Howe, a nurse from Michigan, whom he married October 6, 1912.

Following a brief private practice in Rutherford County, North Carolina, Dr. Washburn began his long connection with Rockefeller organizations as an employee of the Rockefeller Sanitary Commission. As field director for Haywood, Stanley, and Caswell counties in North Carolina, he led a hookworm eradication campaign; he later (May-December 1914) became a full-time health officer in Nash County, North Carolina, as part of a program of community sanitary work funded by The Rockefeller Foundation.

In 1915 Dr. Washburn was appointed field director for the International Health Commission's campaign for control of hookworm in British Guiana and Trinidad. Returning to North Carolina in 1916, Washburn, as county health officer in Wilson County, developed a program of health work intended to serve as a model for other counties and as a training center for International Health Board field staff. In 1917, Dr. Washburn was appointed director of the new state Bureau of County Health Work where he was responsible for the creation of cooperative health programs in ten North Carolina counties.

Dr. Washburn left North Carolina again in 1930 to direct the IHB's Hookworm Campaign in Jamaica and remained to inaugurate and oversee the Malaria Campaign, the Tuberculosis Commission, and the Bureau of Health Education. In 1935, he was appointed regional director for the International Health Division in the West Indies and Central America. Washburn retired from The Rockefeller Foundation in 1939.

Upon retirement, Washburn returned to Rutherfordton, North Carolina, where he was active in state and local public health affairs. He also served as health editor for the Raleigh, North Carolina, "Progressive Farmer" from 1940 to 1951 and wrote several books devoted to his health interests.

Dr. Washburn is the author of "Jamaica Health Stories and Plays" (1929); "The Health Game" (1930); "A Country Doctor in the South Mountains" (1955); "As I Recall" (1960); "Rutherford County and Its Hospital" (1960); and "A History of the North Carolina State Board of Health, 1877-1925" (1966).
For a full list of activities, organizations and honors, see "Who's Who in America," v. 27, 1952-1953, p. 2537.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Benjamin E. Washburn papers contain few items of a personal nature. Consisting of reports, correspondence, scrapbooks, diaries, photographs, books and journals, the papers concern Washburn's employment with the Rockefeller Sanitary Commission (1913-1914) and the International Health Board/Division (1915-1939).

The papers focus on Dr. Washburn's Jamaica years. In addition to various reports and complete scrapbooks, they include correspondence regarding the Hookworm Campaign with the Jamaican Central Board of Health, The Rockefeller Foundation, and the United Fruit Company. Washburn's highly regarded venture in popular health education, the journal "Jamaica Public Health," is also among the Jamaica material.

After the transfer of the IHD Regional Headquarters for the Caribbean region from Kingston, Jamaica, to Havana, Cuba, in 1937, diaries required of Foundation staff are the only documentation of Dr. Washburn's professional activities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Benjamin E. Washburn papers are divided into four series:

controlaccess.subject: Public health
controlaccess.corpname: Rockefeller Sanitary Commission for the Eradication of Hookworm Disease

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the reports, correspondence, publications, memos, and diaries generated as a result of Dr. Washburn's employment with the Rockefeller Sanitary Commission and the International Health Board. The material is arranged geographically and chronologically in four subseries corresponding to Washburn's work in Trinidad, North Carolina, Jamaica, and the Caribbean region.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in this series is arranged geographically and chronologically in four subseries:
Subseries 1 - Trinidad Subseries 2 - North Carolina Subseries 3 - Jamaica Subseries 4 - West Indies and Caribbean
Each subseries is further arranged by type of record.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged by type of record.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged by type of record.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Jamaican files are grouped in several categories. The first, General, contains items which concern all aspects of IHB/D work on the island. Also included in this category are several Jamaican publications (1905-1938) on related subjects, such as mosquitos or vomiting sickness. Dealing with a particular tropical disease with which the IHB/D was active or considering involvement, the remaining Jamaican material is grouped under that malady -- Hookworm, Malaria, Tuberculosis, Yaws, and Yellow Fever.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged by type of record.

did.unittitle: General - Reports - Cooperative Public Health Work
General - Reports - Water Supply, Kingston & St. Andrew
General - Publications - Bureau of Health Education
General - Correspondence - Future of International Health Division (IHD) Work
Field Office Files - West Indies and Caribbean

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged by type of record.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The professional scrapbooks, covering the years 1916-1929 and 1932-1937, were kept by Dr. Washburn or a subordinate. They contain clippings from local newspapers in North Carolina and Jamaica and offer an almost daily record of Dr. Washburn and his staff. The personal scrapbooks, 1916?-1925 and 1931-1934, contain magazine and newspaper clippings on such subjects as North Carolina history, English royalty, and baldness. The scrapbooks are primarily bound volumes; in the early years they are fragments pieced together in approximate chronological order.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The scrapbooks in this series are divided into professional and personal groupings, both of which are chronologically arranged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains items not directly related to Washburn's career with Rockefeller-associated agencies. Included are a manuscript draft of his book "As I Recall," several articles by Washburn on such subjects as hiccups, book and class notes reflecting his health concerns, and items pertaining to Rutherford Hospital, Rutherfordton, North Carolina.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by type of record.

did.unittitle: Notes - Class - London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subjects covered include local living conditions and customs, aspects of International Health Board/Division work, and scenic views.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Photographs are arranged by geographical area:
Trinidad North Carolina Jamaica West Indies Venezuela Surinam Dutch Guiana British Guiana

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: A physician, public health officer, and author, Benjamin E. Washburn was born in Rutherford County, North Carolina, in 1885. Dr. Washburn received undergraduate (1906) and graduate (1909) degrees in English and history from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and graduated from the University of Virginia in 1911 with a degree in medicine. accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Photographs, slides, and other images are open for scholarly research.

RAC is unable to provide access to obsolete media and original digital media. In addition separated media may not yet have undergone stabilization procedures. When feasible, a digital surrogate may be created via special order. All applicable charges will apply. See RAC Head of Archival Services or RAC Head of Digital Programs for details.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for scholarly research. Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (film, audio, video, slides) may be closed to research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be closed to researchers at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/Head of Reference.
